name: London - Love Of Life
body:
They limped painfully down the bank, and once the foremost of
the two men staggered among the rough-strewn rocks.Â  They
were tired and weak, and their faces had the drawn expression of
patience which comes of hardship long endured.Â  They were
heavily burdened with blanket packs which were strapped to their
shoulders.Â  Head-straps, passing across the forehead, helped
support these packs.Â  Each man carried a rifle.Â  They
walked in a stooped posture, the shoulders well forward, the head
still farther forward, the eyes bent upon the ground.
âI wish we had just about two of them cartridges
thatâs layinâ in that cache of ourn,â said the
second man.
His voice was utterly and drearily expressionless.Â  He
spoke without enthusiasm; and the first man, limping into the
milky stream that foamed over the rocks, vouchsafed no reply.
The other man followed at his heels.Â  They did not remove
their foot-gear, though the water was icy coldâso cold that
their ankles ached and their feet went numb.Â  In places the
water dashed against their knees, and both men staggered for
footing.
The man who followed slipped on a smooth boulder, nearly fell,
but recovered himself with a violent effort, at the same time
uttering a sharp exclamation of pain.Â  He seemed faint and
dizzy and put out his free hand while he reeled, as though
seeking support against the air.Â  When he had steadied
himself he stepped forward, but reeled again and nearly
fell.Â  Then he stood still and looked at the other man, who
had never turned his head.
The man stood still for fully a minute, as though debating
with himself.Â  Then he called out:
âI say, Bill, Iâve sprained my ankle.â
Bill staggered on through the milky water.Â  He did not
look around.Â  The man watched him go, and though his face
was expressionless as ever, his eyes were like the eyes of a
wounded deer.
The other man limped up the farther bank and continued
straight on without looking back.Â  The man in the stream
watched him.Â  His lips trembled a little, so that the rough
thatch of brown hair which covered them was visibly
agitated.Â  His tongue even strayed out to moisten them.
âBill!â he cried out.
It was the pleading cry of a strong man in distress, but
Billâs head did not turn.Â  The man watched him go,
limping grotesquely and lurching forward with stammering gait up
the slow slope toward the soft sky-line of the low-lying
hill.Â  He watched him go till he passed over the crest and
disappeared.Â  Then he turned his gaze and slowly took in the
circle of the world that remained to him now that Bill was
gone.
Near the horizon the sun was smouldering dimly, almost
obscured by formless mists and vapors, which gave an impression
of mass and density without outline or tangibility.Â  The man
pulled out his watch, the while resting his weight on one
leg.Â  It was four oâclock, and as the season was near
the last of July or first of August,âhe did not know the
precise date within a week or two,âhe knew that the sun
roughly marked the northwest.Â  He looked to the south and
knew that somewhere beyond those bleak hills lay the Great Bear
Lake; also, he knew that in that direction the Arctic Circle cut
its forbidding way across the Canadian Barrens.Â  This stream
in which he stood was a feeder to the Coppermine River, which in
turn flowed north and emptied into Coronation Gulf and the Arctic
Ocean.Â  He had never been there, but he had seen it, once,
on a Hudson Bay Company chart.
Again his gaze completed the circle of the world about
him.Â  It was not a heartening spectacle.Â  Everywhere
was soft sky-line.Â  The hills were all low-lying.Â 
There were no trees, no shrubs, no grassesânaught but a
tremendous and terrible desolation that sent fear swiftly dawning
into his eyes.
âBill!â he whispered, once and twice;
âBill!â
He cowered in the midst of the milky water, as though the
vastness were pressing in upon him with overwhelming force,
brutally crushing him with its complacent awfulness.Â  He
began to shake as with an ague-fit, till the gun fell from his
hand with a splash.Â  This served to rouse him.Â  He
fought with his fear and pulled himself together, groping in the
water and recovering the weapon.Â  He hitched his pack
farther over on his left shoulder, so as to take a portion of its
weight from off the injured ankle.Â  Then he proceeded,
slowly and carefully, wincing with pain, to the bank.
He did not stop.Â  With a desperation that was madness,
unmindful of the pain, he hurried up the slope to the crest of
the hill over which his comrade had disappearedâmore
grotesque and comical by far than that limping, jerking
comrade.Â  But at the crest he saw a shallow valley, empty of
life.Â  He fought with his fear again, overcame it, hitched
the pack still farther over on his left shoulder, and lurched on
down the slope.
The bottom of the valley was soggy with water, which the thick
moss held, spongelike, close to the surface.Â  This water
squirted out from under his feet at every step, and each time he
lifted a foot the action culminated in a sucking sound as the wet
moss reluctantly released its grip.Â  He picked his way from
muskeg to muskeg, and followed the other manâs footsteps
along and across the rocky ledges which thrust like islets
through the sea of moss.
Though alone, he was not lost.Â  Farther on he knew he
would come to where dead spruce and fir, very small and weazened,
bordered the shore of a little lake, the titchin-nichilie,
in the tongue of the country, the âland of little
sticks.âÂ  And into that lake flowed a small stream,
the water of which was not milky.Â  There was rush-grass on
that streamâthis he remembered wellâbut no timber,
and he would follow it till its first trickle ceased at a
divide.Â  He would cross this divide to the first trickle of
another stream, flowing to the west, which he would follow until
it emptied into the river Dease, and here he would find a cache
under an upturned canoe and piled over with many rocks.Â  And
in this cache would be ammunition for his empty gun, fish-hooks
and lines, a small netâall the utilities for the killing
and snaring of food.Â  Also, he would find flour,ânot
much,âa piece of bacon, and some beans.
Bill would be waiting for him there, and they would paddle
away south down the Dease to the Great Bear Lake.Â  And south
across the lake they would go, ever south, till they gained the
Mackenzie.Â  And south, still south, they would go, while the
winter raced vainly after them, and the ice formed in the eddies,
and the days grew chill and crisp, south to some warm Hudson Bay
Company post, where timber grew tall and generous and there was
grub without end.
These were the thoughts of the man as he strove onward.Â 
But hard as he strove with his body, he strove equally hard with
his mind, trying to think that Bill had not deserted him, that
Bill would surely wait for him at the cache.Â  He was
compelled to think this thought, or else there would not be any
use to strive, and he would have lain down and died.Â  And as
the dim ball of the sun sank slowly into the northwest he covered
every inchâand many timesâof his and Billâs
flight south before the downcoming winter.Â  And he conned
the grub of the cache and the grub of the Hudson Bay Company post
over and over again.Â  He had not eaten for two days; for a
far longer time he had not had all he wanted to eat.Â  Often
he stooped and picked pale muskeg berries, put them into his
mouth, and chewed and swallowed them.Â  A muskeg berry is a
bit of seed enclosed in a bit of water.Â  In the mouth the
water melts away and the seed chews sharp and bitter.Â  The
man knew there was no nourishment in the berries, but he chewed
them patiently with a hope greater than knowledge and defying
experience.
At nine oâclock he stubbed his toe on a rocky ledge, and
from sheer weariness and weakness staggered and fell.Â  He
lay for some time, without movement, on his side.Â  Then he
slipped out of the pack-straps and clumsily dragged himself into
a sitting posture.Â  It was not yet dark, and in the
lingering twilight he groped about among the rocks for shreds of
dry moss.Â  When he had gathered a heap he built a
fire,âa smouldering, smudgy fire,âand put a tin pot
of water on to boil.
He unwrapped his pack and the first thing he did was to count
his matches.Â  There were sixty-seven.Â  He counted them
three times to make sure.Â  He divided them into several
portions, wrapping them in oil paper, disposing of one bunch in
his empty tobacco pouch, of another bunch in the inside band of
his battered hat, of a third bunch under his shirt on the
chest.Â  This accomplished, a panic came upon him, and he
unwrapped them all and counted them again.Â  There were still
sixty-seven.
He dried his wet foot-gear by the fire.Â  The moccasins
were in soggy shreds.Â  The blanket socks were worn through
in places, and his feet were raw and bleeding.Â  His ankle
was throbbing, and he gave it an examination.Â  It had
swollen to the size of his knee.Â  He tore a long strip from
one of his two blankets and bound the ankle tightly.Â  He
tore other strips and bound them about his feet to serve for both
moccasins and socks.Â  Then he drank the pot of water,
steaming hot, wound his watch, and crawled between his
blankets.
He slept like a dead man.Â  The brief darkness around
midnight came and went.Â  The sun arose in the
northeastâat least the day dawned in that quarter, for the
sun was hidden by gray clouds.
At six oâclock he awoke, quietly lying on his
back.Â  He gazed straight up into the gray sky and knew that
he was hungry.Â  As he rolled over on his elbow he was
startled by a loud snort, and saw a bull caribou regarding him
with alert curiosity.Â  The animal was not mere than fifty
feet away, and instantly into the manâs mind leaped the
vision and the savor of a caribou steak sizzling and frying over
a fire.Â  Mechanically he reached for the empty gun, drew a
bead, and pulled the trigger.Â  The bull snorted and leaped
away, his hoofs rattling and clattering as he fled across the
ledges.
The man cursed and flung the empty gun from him.Â  He
groaned aloud as he started to drag himself to his feet.Â  It
was a slow and arduous task.
His joints were like rusty hinges.Â  They worked harshly
in their sockets, with much friction, and each bending or
unbending was accomplished only through a sheer exertion of
will.Â  When he finally gained his feet, another minute or so
was consumed in straightening up, so that he could stand erect as
a man should stand.
He crawled up a small knoll and surveyed the prospect.Â 
There were no trees, no bushes, nothing but a gray sea of moss
scarcely diversified by gray rocks, gray lakelets, and gray
streamlets.Â  The sky was gray.Â  There was no sun nor
hint of sun.Â  He had no idea of north, and he had forgotten
the way he had come to this spot the night before.Â  But he
was not lost.Â  He knew that.Â  Soon he would come to the
land of the little sticks.Â  He felt that it lay off to the
left somewhere, not farâpossibly just over the next low
hill.
He went back to put his pack into shape for travelling.Â 
He assured himself of the existence of his three separate parcels
of matches, though he did not stop to count them.Â  But he
did linger, debating, over a squat moose-hide sack.Â  It was
not large.Â  He could hide it under his two hands.Â  He
knew that it weighed fifteen pounds,âas much as all the
rest of the pack,âand it worried him.Â  He finally set
it to one side and proceeded to roll the pack.Â  He paused to
gaze at the squat moose-hide sack.Â  He picked it up hastily
with a defiant glance about him, as though the desolation were
trying to rob him of it; and when he rose to his feet to stagger
on into the day, it was included in the pack on his back.
He bore away to the left, stopping now and again to eat muskeg
berries.Â  His ankle had stiffened, his limp was more
pronounced, but the pain of it was as nothing compared with the
pain of his stomach.Â  The hunger pangs were sharp.Â 
They gnawed and gnawed until he could not keep his mind steady on
the course he must pursue to gain the land of little
sticks.Â  The muskeg berries did not allay this gnawing,
while they made his tongue and the roof of his mouth sore with
their irritating bite.
He came upon a valley where rock ptarmigan rose on whirring
wings from the ledges and muskegs.Â  Kerâkerâker
was the cry they made.Â  He threw stones at them, but could
not hit them.Â  He placed his pack on the ground and stalked
them as a cat stalks a sparrow.Â  The sharp rocks cut through
his pantsâ legs till his knees left a trail of blood; but
the hurt was lost in the hurt of his hunger.Â  He squirmed
over the wet moss, saturating his clothes and chilling his body;
but he was not aware of it, so great was his fever for
food.Â  And always the ptarmigan rose, whirring, before him,
till their kerâkerâker became a mock to him, and he
cursed them and cried aloud at them with their own cry.
Once he crawled upon one that must have been asleep.Â  He
did not see it till it shot up in his face from its rocky
nook.Â  He made a clutch as startled as was the rise of the
ptarmigan, and there remained in his hand three
tail-feathers.Â  As he watched its flight he hated it, as
though it had done him some terrible wrong.Â  Then he
returned and shouldered his pack.
As the day wore along he came into valleys or swales where
game was more plentiful.Â  A band of caribou passed by,
twenty and odd animals, tantalizingly within rifle range.Â 
He felt a wild desire to run after them, a certitude that he
could run them down.Â  A black fox came toward him, carrying
a ptarmigan in his mouth.Â  The man shouted.Â  It was a
fearful cry, but the fox, leaping away in fright, did not drop
the ptarmigan.
Late in the afternoon he followed a stream, milky with lime,
which ran through sparse patches of rush-grass.Â  Grasping
these rushes firmly near the root, he pulled up what resembled a
young onion-sprout no larger than a shingle-nail.Â  It was
tender, and his teeth sank into it with a crunch that promised
deliciously of food.Â  But its fibers were tough.Â  It
was composed of stringy filaments saturated with water, like the
berries, and devoid of nourishment.Â  He threw off his pack
and went into the rush-grass on hands and knees, crunching and
munching, like some bovine creature.
He was very weary and often wished to restâto lie down
and sleep; but he was continually driven onânot so much by
his desire to gain the land of little sticks as by his
hunger.Â  He searched little ponds for frogs and dug up the
earth with his nails for worms, though he knew in spite that
neither frogs nor worms existed so far north.
He looked into every pool of water vainly, until, as the long
twilight came on, he discovered a solitary fish, the size of a
minnow, in such a pool.Â  He plunged his arm in up to the
shoulder, but it eluded him.Â  He reached for it with both
hands and stirred up the milky mud at the bottom.Â  In his
excitement he fell in, wetting himself to the waist.Â  Then
the water was too muddy to admit of his seeing the fish, and he
was compelled to wait until the sediment had settled.
The pursuit was renewed, till the water was again
muddied.Â  But he could not wait.Â  He unstrapped the tin
bucket and began to bale the pool.Â  He baled wildly at
first, splashing himself and flinging the water so short a
distance that it ran back into the pool.Â  He worked more
carefully, striving to be cool, though his heart was pounding
against his chest and his hands were trembling.Â  At the end
of half an hour the pool was nearly dry.Â  Not a cupful of
water remained.Â  And there was no fish.Â  He found a
hidden crevice among the stones through which it had escaped to
the adjoining and larger poolâa pool which he could not
empty in a night and a day.Â  Had he known of the crevice, he
could have closed it with a rock at the beginning and the fish
would have been his.
Thus he thought, and crumpled up and sank down upon the wet
earth.Â  At first he cried softly to himself, then he cried
loudly to the pitiless desolation that ringed him around; and for
a long time after he was shaken by great dry sobs.
He built a fire and warmed himself by drinking quarts of hot
water, and made camp on a rocky ledge in the same fashion he had
the night before.Â  The last thing he did was to see that his
matches were dry and to wind his watch.Â  The blankets were
wet and clammy.Â  His ankle pulsed with pain.Â  But he
knew only that he was hungry, and through his restless sleep he
dreamed of feasts and banquets and of food served and spread in
all imaginable ways.
He awoke chilled and sick.Â  There was no sun.Â  The
gray of earth and sky had become deeper, more profound.Â  A
raw wind was blowing, and the first flurries of snow were
whitening the hilltops.Â  The air about him thickened and
grew white while he made a fire and boiled more water.Â  It
was wet snow, half rain, and the flakes were large and
soggy.Â  At first they melted as soon as they came in contact
with the earth, but ever more fell, covering the ground, putting
out the fire, spoiling his supply of moss-fuel.
This was a signal for him to strap on his pack and stumble
onward, he knew not where.Â  He was not concerned with the
land of little sticks, nor with Bill and the cache under the
upturned canoe by the river Dease.Â  He was mastered by the
verb âto eat.âÂ  He was hunger-mad.Â  He took
no heed of the course he pursued, so long as that course led him
through the swale bottoms.Â  He felt his way through the wet
snow to the watery muskeg berries, and went by feel as he pulled
up the rush-grass by the roots.Â  But it was tasteless stuff
and did not satisfy.Â  He found a weed that tasted sour and
he ate all he could find of it, which was not much, for it was a
creeping growth, easily hidden under the several inches of
snow.
He had no fire that night, nor hot water, and crawled under
his blanket to sleep the broken hunger-sleep.Â  The snow
turned into a cold rain.Â  He awakened many times to feel it
falling on his upturned face.Â  Day cameâa gray day and
no sun.Â  It had ceased raining.Â  The keenness of his
hunger had departed.Â  Sensibility, as far as concerned the
yearning for food, had been exhausted.Â  There was a dull,
heavy ache in his stomach, but it did not bother him so
much.Â  He was more rational, and once more he was chiefly
interested in the land of little sticks and the cache by the
river Dease.
He ripped the remnant of one of his blankets into strips and
bound his bleeding feet.Â  Also, he recinched the injured
ankle and prepared himself for a day of travel.Â  When he
came to his pack, he paused long over the squat moose-hide sack,
but in the end it went with him.
The snow had melted under the rain, and only the hilltops
showed white.Â  The sun came out, and he succeeded in
locating the points of the compass, though he knew now that he
was lost.Â  Perhaps, in his previous daysâ wanderings,
he had edged away too far to the left.Â  He now bore off to
the right to counteract the possible deviation from his true
course.
Though the hunger pangs were no longer so exquisite, he
realized that he was weak.Â  He was compelled to pause for
frequent rests, when he attacked the muskeg berries and
rush-grass patches.Â  His tongue felt dry and large, as
though covered with a fine hairy growth, and it tasted bitter in
his mouth.Â  His heart gave him a great deal of
trouble.Â  When he had travelled a few minutes it would begin
a remorseless thump, thump, thump, and then leap up and away in a
painful flutter of beats that choked him and made him go faint
and dizzy.
In the middle of the day he found two minnows in a large
pool.Â  It was impossible to bale it, but he was calmer now
and managed to catch them in his tin bucket.Â  They were no
longer than his little finger, but he was not particularly
hungry.Â  The dull ache in his stomach had been growing
duller and fainter.Â  It seemed almost that his stomach was
dozing.Â  He ate the fish raw, masticating with painstaking
care, for the eating was an act of pure reason.Â  While he
had no desire to eat, he knew that he must eat to live.
In the evening he caught three more minnows, eating two and
saving the third for breakfast.Â  The sun had dried stray
shreds of moss, and he was able to warm himself with hot
water.Â  He had not covered more than ten miles that day; and
the next day, travelling whenever his heart permitted him, he
covered no more than five miles.Â  But his stomach did not
give him the slightest uneasiness.Â  It had gone to
sleep.Â  He was in a strange country, too, and the caribou
were growing more plentiful, also the wolves.Â  Often their
yelps drifted across the desolation, and once he saw three of
them slinking away before his path.
Another night; and in the morning, being more rational, he
untied the leather string that fastened the squat moose-hide
sack.Â  From its open mouth poured a yellow stream of coarse
gold-dust and nuggets.Â  He roughly divided the gold in
halves, caching one half on a prominent ledge, wrapped in a piece
of blanket, and returning the other half to the sack.Â  He
also began to use strips of the one remaining blanket for his
feet.Â  He still clung to his gun, for there were cartridges
in that cache by the river Dease.
This was a day of fog, and this day hunger awoke in him
again.Â  He was very weak and was afflicted with a giddiness
which at times blinded him.Â  It was no uncommon thing now
for him to stumble and fall; and stumbling once, he fell squarely
into a ptarmigan nest.Â  There were four newly hatched
chicks, a day oldâlittle specks of pulsating life no more
than a mouthful; and he ate them ravenously, thrusting them alive
into his mouth and crunching them like egg-shells between his
teeth.Â  The mother ptarmigan beat about him with great
outcry.Â  He used his gun as a club with which to knock her
over, but she dodged out of reach.Â  He threw stones at her
and with one chance shot broke a wing.Â  Then she fluttered
away, running, trailing the broken wing, with him in pursuit.
The little chicks had no more than whetted his appetite.Â 
He hopped and bobbed clumsily along on his injured ankle,
throwing stones and screaming hoarsely at times; at other times
hopping and bobbing silently along, picking himself up grimly and
patiently when he fell, or rubbing his eyes with his hand when
the giddiness threatened to overpower him.
The chase led him across swampy ground in the bottom of the
valley, and he came upon footprints in the soggy moss.Â  They
were not his ownâhe could see that.Â  They must be
Billâs.Â  But he could not stop, for the mother
ptarmigan was running on.Â  He would catch her first, then he
would return and investigate.
He exhausted the mother ptarmigan; but he exhausted
himself.Â  She lay panting on her side.Â  He lay panting
on his side, a dozen feet away, unable to crawl to her.Â  And
as he recovered she recovered, fluttering out of reach as his
hungry hand went out to her.Â  The chase was resumed.Â 
Night settled down and she escaped.Â  He stumbled from
weakness and pitched head foremost on his face, cutting his
cheek, his pack upon his back.Â  He did not move for a long
while; then he rolled over on his side, wound his watch, and lay
there until morning.
Another day of fog.Â  Half of his last blanket had gone
into foot-wrappings.Â  He failed to pick up Billâs
trail.Â  It did not matter.Â  His hunger was driving him
too compellinglyâonlyâonly he wondered if Bill, too,
were lost.Â  By midday the irk of his pack became too
oppressive.Â  Again he divided the gold, this time merely
spilling half of it on the ground.Â  In the afternoon he
threw the rest of it away, there remaining to him only the
half-blanket, the tin bucket, and the rifle.
An hallucination began to trouble him.Â  He felt confident
that one cartridge remained to him.Â  It was in the chamber
of the rifle and he had overlooked it.Â  On the other hand,
he knew all the time that the chamber was empty.Â  But the
hallucination persisted.Â  He fought it off for hours, then
threw his rifle open and was confronted with emptiness.Â  The
disappointment was as bitter as though he had really expected to
find the cartridge.
He plodded on for half an hour, when the hallucination arose
again.Â  Again he fought it, and still it persisted, till for
very relief he opened his rifle to unconvince himself.Â  At
times his mind wandered farther afield, and he plodded on, a mere
automaton, strange conceits and whimsicalities gnawing at his
brain like worms.Â  But these excursions out of the real were
of brief duration, for ever the pangs of the hunger-bite called
him back.Â  He was jerked back abruptly once from such an
excursion by a sight that caused him nearly to faint.Â  He
reeled and swayed, doddering like a drunken man to keep from
falling.Â  Before him stood a horse.Â  A horse!Â  He
could not believe his eyes.Â  A thick mist was in them,
intershot with sparkling points of light.Â  He rubbed his
eyes savagely to clear his vision, and beheld, not a horse, but a
great brown bear.Â  The animal was studying him with
bellicose curiosity.
The man had brought his gun halfway to his shoulder before he
realized.Â  He lowered it and drew his hunting-knife from its
beaded sheath at his hip.Â  Before him was meat and
life.Â  He ran his thumb along the edge of his knife.Â 
It was sharp.Â  The point was sharp.Â  He would fling
himself upon the bear and kill it.Â  But his heart began its
warning thump, thump, thump.Â  Then followed the wild upward
leap and tattoo of flutters, the pressing as of an iron band
about his forehead, the creeping of the dizziness into his
brain.
His desperate courage was evicted by a great surge of
fear.Â  In his weakness, what if the animal attacked
him?Â  He drew himself up to his most imposing stature,
gripping the knife and staring hard at the bear.Â  The bear
advanced clumsily a couple of steps, reared up, and gave vent to
a tentative growl.Â  If the man ran, he would run after him;
but the man did not run.Â  He was animated now with the
courage of fear.Â  He, too, growled, savagely, terribly,
voicing the fear that is to life germane and that lies twisted
about lifeâs deepest roots.
The bear edged away to one side, growling menacingly, himself
appalled by this mysterious creature that appeared upright and
unafraid.Â  But the man did not move.Â  He stood like a
statue till the danger was past, when he yielded to a fit of
trembling and sank down into the wet moss.
He pulled himself together and went on, afraid now in a new
way.Â  It was not the fear that he should die passively from
lack of food, but that he should be destroyed violently before
starvation had exhausted the last particle of the endeavor in him
that made toward surviving.Â  There were the wolves.Â 
Back and forth across the desolation drifted their howls, weaving
the very air into a fabric of menace that was so tangible that he
found himself, arms in the air, pressing it back from him as it
might be the walls of a wind-blown tent.
Now and again the wolves, in packs of two and three, crossed
his path.Â  But they sheered clear of him.Â  They were
not in sufficient numbers, and besides they were hunting the
caribou, which did not battle, while this strange creature that
walked erect might scratch and bite.
In the late afternoon he came upon scattered bones where the
wolves had made a kill.Â  The debris had been a caribou calf
an hour before, squawking and running and very much alive.Â 
He contemplated the bones, clean-picked and polished, pink with
the cell-life in them which had not yet died.Â  Could it
possibly be that he might be that ere the day was done!Â 
Such was life, eh?Â  A vain and fleeting thing.Â  It was
only life that pained.Â  There was no hurt in death.Â  To
die was to sleep.Â  It meant cessation, rest.Â  Then why
